records.content: shodh-memory stores memory types in `experience_type` field, NOT `memory_type` — the field name mismatch caused false "broken" conclusion in audit

CraftBazaar (old benchmark app) runs on ports 4000–4001 by default. When re-running MemoryProbe, kill lingering next-server processes and use alternate ports (5000–5001) to avoid silent binding failures
v5 memory audit: 37% noise (vs v4 15%), memory_type field broken (all "unknown"), 16 spurious proactive-context entries; convention knowledge not captured
benchmark/synthetic/scripts/init.sh contains invalid --memory flag that breaks init process

wt-memory derives project name from git repo directory basename — multiple instances with same basename collide; use distinct directory names (e.g., craftbazaar-memory, craftbazaar-baseline) for isolation
Test individual changes before full benchmark run (C01 smoke test catches issues early vs. waiting hours)
Pre-flight validation script before benchmark runs catches issues earlier than runtime detection (hooks, memory health, glob patterns, ports)
Run B (with memory) completed changes 10-12 faster than baseline (4 vs 6 iterations), first sign that memory helps in revision phase, not just early changes
Shared shodh-memory storage between parallel runs with same project name (craftbazaar). No contamination occurred because Run A had no memory hooks, but demonstrates design flaw for future benchmarks

User decision: accuracy over speed advantage — memory integration should prioritize code quality (trap pass rate) over iteration efficiency. A slower but more thorough agent that passes all traps is more valuable than a fast agent that misses cross-cutting bugs.
auto_ingest=False eliminated Conversation memory noise: v5 had 21, v6 has 0 — fix working correctly

Benchmark trap design pattern: use non-standard defaults to trip up agents. Example: custom Tailwind sm:480px (vs default 640px) forces memory recall. The agent's default behavior (using standard values) must be measurably different from the required behavior — this is what makes a grep-checkable convention trap.

Weighted trap categories (A: code-readable x1, B: human override x2, C: forward-looking x3) cannot differentiate memory impact when corrections persist in codebase — design trades accuracy for isolation

async-transcript-extraction code map (auto): bin/wt-hook-memory-save,openspec/changes/async-transcript-extraction/.openspec.yaml,openspec/changes/async-transcript-extraction/design.md,openspec/changes/async-transcript-extraction/proposal.md,openspec/changes/async-transcript-extraction/specs/async-extraction/spec.md,openspec/changes/async-transcript-extraction/tasks.md
Run B (memory-enabled) completed C10-C12 in 4 iterations vs Run A baseline 6 iterations — contradicts expected overhead; memory benefit unclear in practice
TRAP-M requires JSX render check (<Pagination .../>) not import; TRAP-N requires global Toast mount in layout.tsx not component-only; behavioral vs presence distinction
Preflight port-check bug: grep -c outputs "0\n0" on no match, causing integer parse errors — fixed with proper conditional logic
Two-phase workflow: init creates projects+CLAUDE.md variants, then run.sh internally calls claude CLI per session — separates setup from execution
Cannot run `claude` commands from within a Claude session—nested-session protection blocks it. Benchmark validation must run from a regular terminal, not from claude CLI context

benchmark-v8-traps: implementation complete — Added 4 new convention traps (T7-T10) with 3 weighted categories (A: code-readable x1, B: human override x2, C: forward-looking x3). Updated C02 change file with Developer Notes corrections, test scripts with new probes, score.sh with weighted scoring, pre-seed.sh with 10 memories, and all documentation.
Responsive convention trap needs intermediate checkpoints during UI changes, not just final evaluation—requires per-change test coverage.

New benchmark trap type: 'implementation drift' — unlike convention traps (rule stated → compliance tested), drift traps let the agent build freely across multiple changes, then ask for unification. Memory value is in remembering OWN implementation details (which file, what pattern), not a stated rule. This directly tests code-map memory quality. Best for: shared UI components (pagination, toast, loading) that naturally get implemented ad-hoc.

v5-result-bugfixes code map (auto): benchmark/changes/07-stock-rethink.md,benchmark/preflight.sh,benchmark/tests/lib/check-conventions.sh,benchmark/tests/test-03.sh,benchmark/tests/test-04.sh,benchmark/tests/test-05.sh,benchmark/tests/test-08.sh,benchmark/tests/test-hooks.sh

shodh-memory Knowledge Graph is completely empty (0 nodes, 0 edges) despite 56 memories. NER/entity extraction does not run through the CLI wrapper (wt-memory remember). All 5 recall modes (semantic, temporal, hybrid, causal, associative) return identical results without graph data. proactive_context() API is the biggest unused opportunity — it auto-surfaces relevant memories with relevance scores without explicit queries. record_decision() with DecisionContext/Outcome enables structured decision tracking and find_similar_decisions() but is never used. Consolidation system and tier promotions are also inactive (0 events, 0 promotions) — likely because CLI is stateless.
TRAP-B ($queryRaw pain) was missing from v5-results.md trap scoring despite being in scoring-rubric

Stop hook memory reminder pattern: wt-skill-start creates .memory marker when SKILL.md contains wt-memory, wt-hook-stop checks for marker and outputs reminder to agent conversation. Repeated reminders are intentional for compliance.

Benchmark project (craftbazaar) requires full toolchain bootstrap in run-guide: openspec init, wt-tools init (wt-config init or equivalent), memory hook deploy (wt-deploy-hooks / wt-memory-hooks), and openspec hooks init. Both Run A and Run B need identical setup except for CLAUDE.md content (baseline vs with-memory). The bootstrap sequence matters for reproducibility.

wt-memory project isolation uses basename of git root directory. Two repos with the same directory name (e.g. run-a/craftbazaar and run-b/craftbazaar) share the same memory store. For benchmark parallel runs, use different directory names (craftbazaar-baseline vs craftbazaar-memory) to ensure memory isolation. Note: Run A (no memory hooks) never calls wt-memory so there's no actual cross-contamination, but different names are safer.
Preflight port-check grep -c bug: no matches → outputs "0" with exit 1, then || outputs "0" again → PORT_USED parse fails. Fixed.
Memory system needs fundamental redesign—noise/metadata issues won't fix with pruning alone
memory_type finding not broken — stored as experience_type field; confusion came from finding name
auto_ingest=False reduces Conversation noise from 21 to 0; v6 produces 57 memories vs v5's 83 (-31% after noise filtering)
v6 benchmark indítása előtt: git reset + clean dir + preflight check szükséges az init-script State-hez

Agent pattern to fix: after discovering a non-obvious technical finding during exploration or verification, IMMEDIATELY save it as memory before summarizing to the user. Don't wait for the summary — the save should happen at the moment of discovery, not as an afterthought.
HOOK_SKILLS array in wt-memory-hooks grows as new skills added (was 5, now 9); specs documenting this need periodic updates

SYN-03 redesign removes convention probes from test-03/04/05.sh entirely, defers C02 corrections to "starting C03" marker in Developer Notes—ensures only Mode B (with memory hooks) can apply memory-driven fixes across sessions

Benchmark v6 finding: shared shodh-memory storage between Run A and Run B (both named 'craftbazaar'). No contamination occurred because Run A had no hooks/instructions, but use different project names in v7 (e.g. craftbazaar-baseline vs craftbazaar-memory).
wt-memory cmd_import (lines 786-794) already demonstrates full remember() API with entities, metadata, is_failure, is_anomaly — use as reference pattern when extending cmd_remember()

wt-hook-memory-save code-map safety net is gated behind DESIGN_MARKER continue guard (line ~393). If design extraction runs first, the continue skips the code-map block entirely. Code-map has its own CODEMAP_MARKER but never gets evaluated. Fix: move code-map block before the design-marker continue.

proactive-context-and-cli-enhancements code map: bin/wt-memory (CLI — cmd_proactive, cmd_stats, cmd_cleanup, extended cmd_remember + cmd_recall), bin/wt-hook-memory-recall (recall hook — upgraded from recall to proactive with fallback)
v5-benchmark-analysis: completed analysis of v5 A/B benchmark — 12/12 changes both runs, trap score tied 7.5/9, memory noise regressed to 37%, 5 improvement recommendations

v5 benchmark key insight: convention traps (H/I/J/K) don't differentiate at C12 because the sprint retro audit cleans everything up. Differentiation happens during ongoing compliance (C04-C11). New traps MUST include intermediate evaluator checks in per-change test scripts to capture mid-run divergence, not just a C12 audit.
shodh-memory remember() metadata parameter requires Dict[str,str] — all values must be strings. Int/float values cause TypeError. Convert with {str(k):str(v) for k,v in meta.items()}

implementation-drift-traps: implementation complete — Added TRAP-M (pagination UI drift) and TRAP-N (toast/notification drift) to benchmark v6. New trap type: no rule stated, agent builds freely, divergence is natural, C12 asks for unification. TRAP-M: C01→C03→C11→C12 Bug 11 (shared Pagination). TRAP-N: C02→C05→C06→C10→C12 Bug 12 (shared Toast). Tests code-map memory, not convention memory.
Future benchmark tests must include live server verification, not rely on static file checks or post-hoc manual analysis
wt-memory CLI passes memory_type, metadata, is_failure, is_anomaly to Remember() but actual shodh-memory.Memory.remember() uses experience_type parameter name internally
Memory reduced C12 tokens 50% (502K vs 1023K) but produced lower-quality implementation — efficiency gain may come at thoroughness cost
Hook injection strategy in openspec-new-change/SKILL.md uses passive hook-based recall (injected) vs explicit wt-memory recall in command files — different approaches for different contexts
README needs full refresh for release; CLI docs must stay in sync with bin/wt-* commands; traffic warnings required
Memory reduced C12 tokens 50% but produced lower-quality code—efficiency gain may trade off thoroughness

v4 benchmark surprise: iter/change ratio is HIGHER (2.0) than v3 (1.08 memory, 1.58 baseline). Agent no longer combines multiple changes per iteration. Efficiency gap between baseline and memory nearly gone (+5% vs +32%). Hypothesis: transcript extraction hook overhead + strict 2-commit pattern. The v4 bet is on code QUALITY not speed — C12 trap results will validate.
C12 Overview still contains old text "5 bugs" instead of "12 bugs" — leftover from v5 requiring correction
wt-loop bug: glob pattern "0*.md" only matched files 01-09, missing 10-12 because they start with "1". Fixed to "[0-9]*.md"
v5 bugfixes effective: auto_ingest=False eliminates Conversation noise (0 vs 21 in v5), change tagging 100% enforced by hooks
Memory system quality degraded in v5: 37% noise rate (vs v4 15%), with 16 spurious proactive-context entries. Convention-level knowledge not being captured properly.
Open WebUI docker container was occupying port 3000; port discovery required checking /proc/net/tcp{,6} and docker ps when ss/lsof were insufficient
Memory type stored in experience_type field, not memory_type — auto_ingest=True creates unwanted Conversation noise
Multi-instance benchmark directories must use distinct suffixes (-memory, -baseline) to ensure wt-memory project name isolation — basename resolution causes collisions

The v8 benchmark uses synthetic repos (probe-a, probe-b) with Mode A having no memory hooks and Mode B having full shodh-memory integration. Both modes run 5 parallel Claude sessions (C01-C05) and compare final scores. Current design assumes later changes won't read earlier corrections — an invalid assumption.

v5-result-bugfixes: Pass `auto_ingest=False` in `wt-memory proactive` command. In `wt-hook-memory-save` transcript extraction, prepend `change:$change_name` to the tags string before passing to `wt-memory remember`. Enhance the existing transcript extraction LLM prompt to also scan for convention...
Preflight check: run 14 assertions (git init, port bind, CLAUDE.md exists, etc.) before wt-loop start via preflight.sh script

transcript-memory-extraction: implementation complete — enhanced wt-hook-memory-save with transcript-based LLM extraction (haiku) as agent-independent 4th memory layer. Reads transcript_path from Stop hook stdin, detects opsx/openspec skill usage, extracts insights via claude -p --model haiku, saves to wt-memory. Existing commit-based logic preserved as parallel path.

Memory benchmark design: The 6-change CraftBazaar project is structured so changes 1-3 create knowledge (env quirks, design decisions) and changes 4-6 consume it. The critical trap is Change 3's order architecture (flat vs nested) which cascades into C4 (discount scope), C5 (payout split), and C6 (per-vendor status). This makes C3 the highest-value memory save point and C6 the highest-value recall point.
v5 analysis shows convention traps (H/I/J/K) don't differentiate at C12—sprint retro audit cleans everything. Differentiation happens C04-C11 during compliance.
v5 specs (benchmark-testing, memory-save-hook, convention-extraction) were archived but never synced to main—treat as new capabilities in future changes
Drift traps (M-N) differ fundamentally from convention traps (H-L): no rule stated upfront, natural divergence during implementation, unification challenge at C12

Planned but not yet implemented: shodh-memory export/import feature. Design from explore session: project-level export/import that dumps all memory records into a single file with unique IDs. Import reads that file on another machine. Key requirement: unique record IDs must prevent duplication because users will run export/import back-and-forth between machines working on the same project. No change was created — only explored.
wt-hook-memory-save code-map block is gated by DESIGN_MARKER continue guard (line 393) — if design extraction runs first, continue skips entire loop including code-map extraction
Invalid --memory flags exist in benchmark/synthetic/scripts/init.sh that contradict current CLI interface

wire-memory-hooks-deploy: implementation complete — wt-deploy-hooks now deploys memory hooks by default (wt-hook-memory-recall + wt-hook-memory-save), with --no-memory flag for baselines, upgrade path for existing configs, simplified benchmark scripts, aligned smart-recall spec to git log reality, updated docs with automatic hooks section and architecture diagram
v5 benchmark specs (benchmark-testing, memory-save-hook, convention-extraction) were archived but never synced to main openspec/specs/. Treat as new capabilities in subsequent changes.

Convention probes (e.g., "Comment error codes use dot.notation") in FAIL messages must never appear in test output scripts—agents read failure text and apply the "hint" as the fix, making all tests pass regardless of memory
`MemoryClient.proactive_context(auto_ingest=True)` auto-saves context string as Conversation-type memory — this is the noise source (21 entries in Run B)

benchmark-v9 redesign: Two critical fixes for zero-delta: (1) removed convention probes from test-03/04/05.sh — probes were leaking expected conventions via failure messages, (2) C02 Developer Notes now say 'starting C03' so corrections don't bake into C02 code. Also fixed T9 grep for JS destructuring, reclassified traps (A:5 code-readable, B:1 fmtDate nuance, C:4 memory-only). Max weighted score 44.
MemoryProbe benchmark requires separate terminal tabs for parallel mode A/B execution (~30 min each)—cannot be automated from within Claude sessions

bulk-archive-memory-hooks: Added wt-memory self-reflection hooks to bulk-archive skill (SKILL.md + command file), matching regular archive pattern. Updated readme-guide coverage matrix to include bulk-archive.
grep-based scoring patterns must match actual source syntax — JS object keys are unquoted (paging:) not JSON-quoted ("paging":), patterns need regex alternation
Auto-stop triggered incorrectly when changes had "no-tasks" status — detected 9 complete + 3 no-tasks = done, skipped starting C10-C12 entirely
wt-loop background tasks exit immediately after spawn; actual benchmark continues in child process—check wt-loop status, not task output file
Memory reduced C12 tokens 50% (502K→1023K) but lower-quality implementation—efficiency ≠ thoroughness, may cause overconfidence
Trust already configured in benchmark dirs; wt-loop start can be invoked directly without additional setup; parallel runs monitored via wt-loop status commands

Claude Code hook stdout injection is the only way for shell hooks to communicate back to the agent. Reminders via stdout get injected into the conversation as system messages. Repeated reminders on every Stop event increase compliance vs single reminder.
All benchmark configurations must define fixed ports in CLAUDE.md templates + init scripts — avoid dynamic port allocation to prevent conflicts with background services

synthetic-memory-benchmark: implementation complete — MemoryProbe benchmark at benchmark/synthetic/ with 5 changes, 6 non-standard convention traps (pagination/entries+paging, errors/fault+reason, soft-delete/removedAt, dates/fmtDate, IDs/prefix+nanoid, ok-wrapper), 15 automated probes, 3 test modes (A/B/C), init/run/pre-seed/score scripts. Tasks 7.2-7.3 remain (manual C01 run + grep pattern verification).

Memory test suite design: 4-layer approach — (1) CLI functional tests with real shodh-memory and isolated SHODH_STORAGE, (2) hook file patching tests with temp git repo, (3) marker/reminder pipeline tests for .memory mechanism, (4) compliance tests verifying all skill+command files contain wt-memory hooks. Real Claude agent spy testing (C approach) deferred as too expensive/flaky for automated testing.
score.sh grep patterns expect JSON syntax ("paging":) but JS source uses unquoted keys (paging:) — requires separate patterns for format validation
Two trap types: Convention (rule stated → compliance tested) vs Drift (no rule → free build → unification tested)
Responsive-convention-trap and implementation-drift-traps modify same 17 benchmark files — process by file to avoid conflicts
Port 4000/4001 silently fail to bind if CraftBazaar next-server running — server exits without error. Use ports 5000+ to avoid conflicts
openspec-new-change uses hook-injected memory (passive) vs explicit recall calls (active) — both valid, clarify strategy choice
V5 trap scoring: tie at 7.5/9 (Run B +0.5 convention traps, -0.5 original traps); no clear memory advantage despite 23% more tokens in Run B overall
Memory reduced tokens 50% (502K vs 1023K) but lower-quality output — efficiency vs thoroughness tradeoff
proactive_context() returns a dict wrapper {memories: [...], latency_ms, ingested_id, config, count} — not a list directly. Parameter is max_results not limit.

benchmark-v8-traps design decision: Use 3 weighted trap categories (A: code-readable x1, B: human override x2, C: forward-looking x3) to isolate memory's unique value. Category B creates spec-vs-memory conflict via C02 Developer Notes corrections. Category C tests advice for features that don't exist yet. This amplifies the A-B delta on the dimensions where memory matters most.
shodh-memory stores memory type in `experience_type` field, not `memory_type` — inspection of compiled wrapper revealed correct signature with metadata parameters
For MemoryProbe benchmark runs, use ports 5000–5001 instead of 4000–4001 to avoid collision with residual CraftBazaar processes

T9 (POST body for batch ops) grep pattern `req\.body\.\w*[Ii]ds` fails to match destructuring syntax like `const { eventIds } = req.body` — pattern only catches direct property access `req.body.eventIds`. This caused 0/1 probe scores in both modes.
User communicates in Hungarian — respond in Hungarian for OpenSpec skills and technical discussion
37% of memories lack `change:` tags — existing hook doesn't inject them; needs explicit tag parameter in memory save calls
Port identification requires multi-tool approach (ss, netstat, /proc, docker ps) — single command fails; Open WebUI docker container on 3000 was blocking benchmark
TRAP-B ($queryRaw pain) missing from v5 analysis despite being in original rubric; scoring uses 5 traps (A/D/E/F/G) when B doesn't trigger, not 6
When combining `cd` with background process (`&`), the cd is lost in subshell scope — use fully absolute paths or avoid backgrounding that command
Port 3000/3001→4000/4001 migration needed to avoid Open WebUI conflicts in benchmark environments
User chose to continue benchmark from C10 rather than restart — valued preserving C01-C09 progress and testing memory persistence over clean slate

responsive-convention-trap: implementation complete — Added TRAP-L to benchmark v6. Custom sm:480px breakpoints + ResponsiveContainer convention established in C01, recall tested in C02/C05/C06, preservation tested in C10/C11 redesigns, audit in C12 Bug 10. Intermediate test checks in test-01 through test-12 measure ongoing compliance, not just final C12 audit.

openspec archive spec sync frequently fails when delta specs reference requirement headers that have been renamed or restructured in main specs. Use --skip-specs to force archive, or --no-validate --skip-specs for changes with malformed delta specs. 8/14 changes needed --skip-specs in this batch.
test-12.sh passes 71% of checks without running server — payout check auto-passes when no_multi_vendor_orders, TRAP-M grep check doesn't catch JSX rendering
Evaluator notes for traps should appear in BOTH change definition AND benchmark change files (as TRAP-X sections) for clarity
working on proactive context integration for shodh memory

C02 Developer Notes persist through init.sh sed strip — sed only removes EVALUATOR NOTES section after, not Agent Input containing Developer Notes

fix-agent-memory-discipline: implementation complete — added Discover→Save→Tell ordering pattern to CLAUDE.md and all 5 skill pairs (explore, ff, apply, continue, verify) to ensure agents save non-obvious discoveries before summarizing to user
Memory reduces implementation time & token usage but may reduce code quality—Run B used 50% fewer tokens on C12 (502K vs 1023K) but scored lower (9/12 vs 11/12 bugs found)
Memory degradation: 83 entries, 37% noise, broken memory_type field (all "unknown"), 16 proactive-context spam entries

Multi-change file conflicts avoided by processing file-by-file rather than change-by-change when changes share target files

benchmark/synthetic/scripts/init.sh uses invalid --memory flag that should be removed
memory_type field in v5 audit was false positive — actual storage uses experience_type in JSON, types (Learning/Context/Decision/Conversation) present and working correctly

User preference: save detailed benchmark analysis as .md files under benchmark/ directory (e.g., benchmark/v4-results.md, benchmark/analysis-v3-v4-comparison.md). Don't just use wt-memory for insights — create proper documentation files for sharing and review.
Memory hooks explicitly excluded from onboarding skill; only deployed to core CLI/GUI skills
test-12.sh passes 71% without running server—payout check auto-passes on no_multi_vendor_orders, TRAP-M grep misses JSX rendering
Relative paths in DB/file config use __dirname so work correctly when server started from different directory — no need to change working directory
Memory integration NOT required for openspec onboarding skill — focus on CLI/UI deploy hooks instead
proactive_context() has auto_ingest=True by default, creating unwanted "Conversation" noise in memories — pass auto_ingest=False to suppress
wt-control menu labels need to explicitly state what each button installs/deploys for user clarity
Changed file collection should aggregate across all commits in a session, not just current commit — prevents incomplete codebase coverage tracking
Skill definition files (SKILL.md) must be kept in sync with actual hook implementations and CLI flag signatures — cross-reference during audit/deployment

bulk-archive-memory-hooks: Added wt-memory self-reflection hooks to bulk-archive skill (both SKILL.md and command file), matching regular archive pattern. Updated readme-guide coverage matrix. spec-driven schema, completed successfully.
Test memory fixes and convention extraction BEFORE running full benchmark (preflight + smoke test), not after sprint retro
score.sh grep patterns must match both JS unquoted keys (paging:) and JSON quoted keys ("paging") — use [[:space:]] for robust matching
Implement three-tier pre-run testing: isolated hooks test, preflight.sh infra check, C01 smoke test before full 12-change run

benchmark-v8-traps lesson: score.sh grep patterns must handle both JS object syntax (unquoted keys like 'paging:') and JSON syntax (quoted keys like '"paging"'). Pattern fix: use 'paging[[:space:]]*[:{]|"paging"' instead of just '"paging"'. Also, centralized error middleware files need to be included in file search patterns, not just route-specific files.

v3 memory quality: 66 memories, 27% noise. Reflection hook dominated (62%), agent inline saves only 8%. Most valuable memories were environment gotchas (Prisma v7, cookie names, port conflicts), not architecture summaries.
bash brace expansion gotcha: ${var:-{}} is parsed incorrectly — the closing brace is consumed by the parameter expansion. Use ${var:-"{}"} instead.
Convention extraction benefits from capping output at 2 (max 5 insights, but conventions separately) to prevent noise
Starting Node server with PORT env in background subshell loses cd context — use absolute paths for script location

v8 benchmark has a fundamental design flaw: "Category B" traps (human override x2 weight) cannot be evaluated fairly because C02 corrections physically modify the codebase, so later changes (C03-C05) inherit the corrected patterns regardless of memory availability. Result: 0 delta between Mode A (no memory) and Mode B (with memory) for all v8 traps.

Soft hooks in SKILL.md (prompt instructions for wt-memory recall/remember) are unreliable — agent can skip them. Solution: wt-hook-stop (hard Claude Code Stop hook) checks for .memory marker file and outputs a reminder to stdout, which gets injected as a system message. wt-skill-start creates the marker by grepping SKILL.md for wt-memory at registration time.
test type check
Port migration 3000→4000, 3001→4001 across 21 files (configs, templates, test scripts) to avoid Open WebUI conflict and establish fixed benchmark baseline

Benchmark v6 trap design insight: Convention traps (H-L) test rule compliance — a rule is stated, memory helps recall it. Implementation drift traps (M-N) test code-map recall — no rule exists, the agent's own implementation choices diverge naturally, and memory of WHERE and HOW things were built helps during unification. The key v5 finding was that convention traps don't differentiate well at C12 audit (both agents can grep), so intermediate per-change checks are essential. Drift traps differentiate because knowing WHAT each page does (not just WHERE) saves search time.
Benchmark changes need mid-run convention compliance checks, not just post-run validation
Future benchmark runs should include live server validation in test infrastructure, not post-hoc manual verification
Benchmark v3 results documented

Opus 4.6 + OpenSpec ff→apply pipeline produces 0 test-fix cycles—both v5 and v6 had zero iteration-level rework despite 12 complex changes, suggesting implementation reliability or insufficient test coverage
Benchmark-specific fixes should be separated from general CLI/GUI/deploy fixes — keep changes focused and reusable
Benchmark agent implements changes without mid-run testing, catching bugs only at C12 retro — suggests acceptance tests needed in change definitions
Convention extraction not yet in code-map (0/4 files tracked) — would catch pattern changes without source review
claude CLI cannot be invoked from within a Claude Code session (nested session protection) — benchmark run.sh must execute from plain terminal
Use different project names for isolated benchmark runs to avoid shodh-memory cross-contamination
All benchmark configs (CLAUDE.md templates, run-guide.md, project-spec.md, test scripts) must reference same port pairs consistently; update PORT defaults in init scripts and test harnesses together
All API responses must follow `{ ok: true/false, fault?: string, entries?: [], paging?: { page, limit, total } }` format with `<prefix>_<id>` naming for generated IDs (e.g., `cmt_...`, `evt_...`)
proactive_context() API confirmed working at ~84ms, returns relevance_score (float 0-1) and relevance_reason (string). hasattr check needed for version compatibility fallback.
Sprint retro audit in CraftBazaar acts as a reset point—late traps become ineffective because agents can ignore non-compliance if it gets cleaned up later.
For benchmark runs with shared memory projects: each git repo gets its own memory store by project name; isolate benchmarks by clearing Run B's memory before starting (Run A irrelevant as baseline)

Benchmark v1 finding: sequential non-repeating changes don't test memory well. Memory value shows in requirement reversals (stakeholder changes mind), cross-context consistency (same pattern needed in different sessions), and error recurrence (same bug in different changes). Organic traps (IF agent hits error) are weak; forced contradictions (MUST deal with reversal) are strong.

Bulk archived 14 changes on shodh-memory-integration branch: memory-browse-upgrade, agent-insight-memory, developer-memory-docs, proactive-memory, shodh-openspec-hooks, shodh-memory-gui, shodh-memory-integration, gui-debug-logging, disable-auto-orphan-kill, remove-openspec-coupling, hybrid-editor-awareness, fix-editor-open-tty-fallback, fix-linux-window-focus, editor-detection-overhaul. 6 with spec sync, 8 with --skip-specs due to header mismatches in main specs.
Run B (memory-enabled) completed C10-C12 faster than baseline (4 vs 6 iterations) — first time memory run used fewer iterations, suggesting cumulative benefit in multi-phase tasks
Server silently fails to bind when port occupied — no error shown, process stays running but doesn't listen

responsive-convention-trap code map: benchmark/changes/01-product-catalog.md (TRAP-L establishment + responsive reqs), benchmark/changes/02-shopping-cart.md (TRAP-L recall), benchmark/changes/05-checkout.md (TRAP-L recall), benchmark/changes/06-order-workflow.md (TRAP-L recall), benchmark/changes/10-cart-ux-correction.md (TRAP-L preservation), benchmark/changes/11-vendor-dashboard-redesign.md (TRAP-L preservation), benchmark/changes/12-sprint-retro.md (Bug 10 audit), benchmark/tests/test-01.sh through test-12.sh (intermediate TRAP-L checks), benchmark/scoring-rubric.md (TRAP-L scoring table)

v5-result-bugfixes: Fixed memory noise (auto_ingest=False), added change: tags to transcript extraction, convention extraction via LLM, code-map safety net improvements, mid-run convention compliance checks in test scripts, TRAP-F explicit requirement, test-hooks.sh + preflight.sh test infrastructure

The regular archive skill only has self-reflection memory hooks (no recall, no mid-flow). Recall and mid-flow hooks are specific to creative/interactive skills (explore, ff, apply, new, continue). Archive skills are mechanical wrap-up operations.

OpenSpec has TWO separate file types per skill: .claude/skills/<name>/SKILL.md (loaded when LLM calls Skill tool) and .claude/commands/opsx/<id>.md (loaded when user types /opsx:<id>). The npm package generates both from different built-in templates. Custom additions to SKILL.md are NOT reflected in command files — both must be edited. After openspec update --force, command files are overwritten from npm templates, losing customizations. Always sync memory steps to BOTH files.
T9 grep pattern matches `req.body.eventIds` but actual code uses destructuring `const { eventIds } = req.body` — patterns must account for destructuring syntax

Synthetic benchmark trap categories: Category A (T1-T6): stateless functional fixes, Category B (T7-T8, T10): convention-driven multi-session leaks, Category C (T9+): memory-dependent fixes requiring session context—each category must be physically reorganized in score.sh

Benchmark evolution pattern: v3 memory = faster but sloppier, v4 memory = same speed but (hopefully) more thorough. The key metric shifted from iterations-per-change to trap-pass-rate. Agent compliance with memory save instructions improved dramatically (8%→43% inline saves) through combination of better skill prompts and automatic transcript extraction as safety net.

Benchmark init: openspec init --tools claude skips config.yaml in non-interactive mode. Must create it manually. Also must pre-create OpenSpec changes with proposals using 'openspec new change' + copying proposal.md, otherwise openspec list returns empty and the agent has no starting point.
Background bash wrapper exits immediately after starting wt-loop; actual benchmark runs in loop process (don't trust exit code for completion status)
Centralized middleware (errors.js) makes distributed grep-based validation unreliable — single-point checks don't capture architecture
When resuming incomplete benchmarks, continue from latest checkpoint rather than restart — preserves code state and tests memory transfer across sessions

async-transcript-extraction: Use `&` + `disown` to background the entire `extract_from_transcript` call, wrapped in a helper that handles lockfile and cleanup. Use `.wt-tools/.transcript-extraction.lock` with PID check. If lock exists and PID is alive, skip. Otherwise, take lock. The backgrounded...
Memory improves implementation completeness (47% functional delta) more than convention adherence (20% grep delta) in synthetic tasks
Node server fails silently when PORT env var conflicts with running process — use lsof -i :PORT to diagnose; kill previous process or use different port
SKILL.md uses injected hook-based memory recall (wt-hook-memory-recall) vs explicit wt-memory recall in command files — different strategies, both valid
Dual-file architecture: when adding features to OpenSpec skills, always check and edit both SKILL.md and the corresponding command file. Use diff to verify they match.
MemoryProbe benchmarks must run from plain terminal (not Claude Code session) — init.sh can run anywhere, but run.sh must be executed manually from ~/bench/probe-a and ~/bench/probe-b directories
CLAUDE.md template-ek "5 bugs" mondanak C12-re, de valójában 12 bug van — inkonzisztencia a baseline.md és with-memory.md file-okban

memory-git-sync: implementation complete — wt-memory sync push/pull/status commands using orphan branch 'wt-memory' with user/machine namespacing, .sync-state for skip detection (normalized content hash on push, commit hash on pull), temp dir for push, git show for pull. 22 tests covering identity, push, pull, status, graceful degradation. Export hash uses jq -S normalization to strip volatile fields (exported_at, last_accessed, access_count, importance).
memory-save-reminder-hook: Added .memory marker file to wt-skill-start and memory reminder output to wt-hook-stop. Schema: spec-driven. All artifacts and tasks complete, specs synced.
C02 corrections (dot.notation, result keys) become part of source code, so Mode A (no memory) also applies them when reading subsequent changes — code is the memory, creating zero delta
Benchmark memory store is identified by repo name (craftbazaar), not per-run isolation — Run A and Run B share same store unless explicitly purged before Run B
Shared memory DB between Run A/B (same project name) design flaw. No contamination occurred but v7+ needs different names
Preflight port-check: `grep -c` outputs "0" AND exits 1 on no-match, then `|| echo 0` outputs another "0" → PORT_USED="0\n0" → integer parse fails
wt-control GUI menu labels must explicitly state what each deploy/hook button installs (clarity requirement from user)
Memory provides +47% functional gain but only +20% convention gain because conventions are already documented in project-spec.md
Run B completed C10-C12 in 4 iterations vs Run A in 6 — memory provided marginal speed gain on complex tasks despite equal trap scoring
Both dev servers persist after benchmark—ports 4000/4001 remain occupied, manual cleanup needed between runs to avoid stale state

The 3-category weighting scheme (A: x1, B: x2, C: x3) was designed to isolate memory's value, but the Category B mechanism (which requires "code-readable" vs "memory-assisted" differentiation) is broken because code corrections become part of the permanent codebase. This needs architectural rethinking before v9.

v3 benchmark: memory gave +32% efficiency (13 vs 19 iter) but WORSE code quality — Run B failed 3.5/5 traps vs Run A 1/5. Speed-thoroughness tradeoff: fewer iterations meant less code re-reading, causing missed nuances on C12 sprint-retro (API envelope, payout algorithm, stock validation).
Run B (memory) completed C10-C12 in 4 vs 6 iterations—first memory speed win. Combined trap score tied (7.5/9), no clear advantage
Memory save in opsx:archive is a skill step (step 7), not automated by hook — agent must explicitly execute it or memory won't save after archiving
21 Conversation-type memories from proactive-context hook have no value; these are noise entries that should be tagged or filtered
Working on change: v5-result. Implementation in progress.

Benchmark v6 test weakness: test-12 passes 71% of checks (15/21) with NO running server. Payout check auto-passes on no_multi_vendor_orders. TRAP-M checks import not render (grep 'Pagination' vs grep '<Pagination'). Fix: add behavioral curl checks, fail on missing test data, check render not import.
First change (C01 product-catalog) typically longest — 356K tokens to build full Next.js/Prisma project from scratch; subsequent changes faster
Use absolute paths in bash loops with background processes — relative `cd` gets lost in subshell contexts

benchmark-v8-traps code map: benchmark/synthetic/changes/02-tags-filtering.md (C02 correction change with Developer Notes), benchmark/synthetic/scripts/score.sh (weighted scoring engine with T1-T10 probes), benchmark/synthetic/scoring-rubric.md (trap definitions and probe matrix), benchmark/synthetic/scripts/pre-seed.sh (Mode C memory injection T1-T10), benchmark/synthetic/claude-md/with-memory.md (agent CLAUDE.md with correction recall), benchmark/synthetic/tests/test-03.sh test-04.sh test-05.sh (convention probe tests)
"Cross-screen implementation divergence" trap: same feature implemented differently on different screens, then unified later — creates abstraction/consolidation challenge for agents
v5 archived specs (benchmark-testing, memory-save-hook) never synced to main. Treat as new capabilities in subsequent changes

Skill name mapping for SKILL.md lookup: opsx:* → openspec-* prefix, wt:* → wt (single skill directory). This mapping is needed when locating .claude/skills/<name>/SKILL.md from the colon-separated skill invocation name.
wt-hook-memory-save code-map block gated by DESIGN_MARKER continue guard. Runs before guard → code-map skipped entirely
Memory provides redundant convention help (both modes follow spec.md) but improves functional completeness: 97% vs 50% test pass rates
Memory-hooks spec referenced outdated skill count (5 vs actual 9 available) — needs dynamic or manual audit before spec publication
Shared shodh-memory storage between benchmarks with same project name causes cross-contamination risk—use distinct names per run
When benchmark hits auto-stop due to incomplete changes, continue rather than restart to preserve C01-C09 baseline and test memory in fresh context
Shell test helpers need careful result handling — eval can fail silently; prefer explicit conditionals over string-based logic
openspec-new-change/SKILL.md uses passive hook injection (wt-hook-memory-recall) vs explicit wt-memory recall in new.md — different strategies, both valid

memory-benchmark-protocol: implementation complete — created benchmark/ directory with 17 files: project-spec, 6 change definitions (with trap docs + evaluator notes), 2 CLAUDE.md variants (baseline vs with-memory), scoring rubric, diagnostic framework, 3 templates (annotation, metrics JSON, comparison report), run guide with full bootstrap commands, and results collection guide

MemoryProbe synthetic benchmark design: 5 small changes (2 seed + 1 gap + 3 probe), 6 non-standard convention traps, separate Claude sessions per change (fresh context), automated grep scoring. Key insight: non-standard conventions (e.g. 'fault.reason' not 'error.message', 'removedAt' not 'deletedAt', 'entries' not 'data') ensure only memory or code-reading can produce correct answer. Three modes: A=baseline, B=full-memory, C=pre-seeded. Expected: 30-60 min total vs 4-5h for CraftBazaar.

transcript-memory-extraction: Scan the JSONL file with grep for `"skill":"opsx:` and `"skill":"openspec-` patterns to detect whether skills were used. Use `claude` CLI in print mode with haiku model for cheap, reliable insight extraction. Unset `CLAUDECODE` env var to avoid nesting check. Extract...
v5 benchmark has 12 changes (C01-C12) organized as: C01-C03 explicit traps, C04-C06 implicit traps, C07-C09 revision phase, C10-C12 feedback/retro phase
score.sh grep patterns expect JSON-style quoted keys but JS source uses unquoted keys — patterns need both formats for accurate scoring
test-12.sh passes 71% checks with NO server (static grep). Payout check auto-passes on no multi_vendor_orders — not behavioral test

memory-export-import: implementation complete — CLI export/import commands with UUID-based dedup (4-level check via metadata.original_id), GUI Export/Import buttons in MemoryBrowseDialog, 15 CLI tests (including full A→B→A roundtrip), 5 GUI tests, docs updated.
Benchmark-specific fixes belong in benchmark/ scripts, not core tool CLI validation — separate concerns clearly

wt-control Team Sync feature generates significant GitHub API traffic (git fetch/push on every poll cycle). Default refresh/poll timeout should be 2 minutes minimum to avoid rate limiting. Document this prominently in wt-control docs section.
Test suite can pass 71% of checks without running server—payout check auto-passes on no_multi_vendor_orders, TRAP-M checks import via grep not render, reveals false-positive results
Glob pattern 0*.md only matches 0-9, not 10+ — use [0-9]*.md or *.md with filtering for numbered files

MemoryProbe v7 methodology: baseline (Mode A, no memory) vs memory-augmented (Mode B, with shodh-memory) — memory showed +20% convention adherence and +47% functional test pass rate over ~9 min per mode
Visual GUI design quality (image rendering, styling) explicitly not part of benchmark evaluation — benchmark measures schema/API/behavior only
3 weighted trap categories isolate memory's value: A=code-readable (x1), B=human-override (x2), C=forward-looking (x3) — Category B is memory-specific
Testing during implementation (not post-release) would catch bugs earlier — current cycle: implement → C12 retro → discover broken features → patch (propose test-in-progress loop)
memory_type field is completely broken — all values are "unknown", making memory audit by type impossible. Needs fixing in memory system

Benchmark should include a diagnostic/gap analysis dimension: not just measure with/without memory, but also identify WHERE memory failed to help and WHY — to drive improvements to the memory system itself. This includes: missed recall opportunities, low-quality saves, missing memory types, and timing issues (saved too late to help).
score.sh grep patterns expect JSON syntax ("paging":) but JS source uses unquoted keys (paging:) — patterns need both formats

wt-loop fixes for benchmark compatibility: (1) claude -p goes into Tl (stopped) state when run through pipe+tee because it loses the controlling terminal - fix: use 'script -f -q' to create a PTY instead of 'tee'. (2) timeout creates new process group causing SIGTTOU - fix: use 'timeout --foreground'. (3) Nested session protection blocks claude -p when launched from within Claude Code - fix: 'env -u CLAUDECODE'. (4) wt-loop default prompt was tasks.md-centric, ignoring CLAUDE.md workflow - fix: prompt now directs agent to read CLAUDE.md first. (5) Claude Code requires project trust acceptance on first run in new directory - must run claude interactively once before wt-loop can work.
For benchmark continuation decisions: prioritize high-value changes (C10-C12 over C01-C09 repeat) even when multi-hour investment, especially when memory system is being tested
v6 baseline (Run A) completes ~20min faster than memory-augmented run (Run B); both reach 12/12 changes in ~2h
CLAUDE.md templates in baseline.md and with-memory.md incorrectly stated "5 bugs" for Change 12 — should be "12 bugs" (fixed: 5→12 across 4 lines)
DESIGN_MARKER continue guard at line ~393 skips code-map block entirely if design extraction runs first—safety net is broken

v6-test-fixes code map: benchmark/tests/test-12.sh (payout/TRAP-M/TRAP-N/vendor checks), benchmark/tests/test-02.sh (TRAP-G checkout link), benchmark/changes/12-sprint-retro.md (Bug 11/12 explicit criteria), benchmark/changes/02-shopping-cart.md (checkout link criterion), bin/wt-hook-memory-save (code-map unconditional), benchmark/claude-md/with-memory.md (recall-then-verify), benchmark/init-baseline.sh + init-with-memory.sh (DB isolation via dir names)

CLAUDE.md deference deadlock: The proactive memory instruction says 'defer to skill hooks if the active skill has wt-memory hooks'. But this checks the SKILL.md on disk, while the LLM receives the command file prompt (which may lack hooks). Result: ambient memory defers, but the prompt has no hooks either → nothing saves. Fix: defer only if the ACTUAL prompt received contains wt-memory steps, not based on SKILL.md file existence.

implementation-drift-traps code map: benchmark/changes/01-product-catalog.md (TRAP-M pagination drift point), benchmark/changes/03-multi-vendor.md (TRAP-M divergence), benchmark/changes/02-shopping-cart.md (TRAP-N feedback drift point), benchmark/changes/05-checkout.md (TRAP-N error feedback), benchmark/changes/06-order-workflow.md (TRAP-N status feedback), benchmark/changes/10-cart-ux-correction.md (TRAP-N toast intro), benchmark/changes/11-vendor-dashboard-redesign.md (TRAP-M pagination spec), benchmark/changes/12-sprint-retro.md (Bug 11 Pagination + Bug 12 Toast), benchmark/tests/test-12.sh (TRAP-M/N checks), benchmark/scoring-rubric.md (TRAP-M + TRAP-N scoring tables)

README audit found 5+ missing CLI commands not in mandatory sections — doc generation tools must validate against actual bin/ directory

0*.md in wt-loop only matched 01-09, missing 10-12. Fixed with [0-9]*.md. Caused premature auto-stop
All API responses use consistent wrapper: {ok:true, entries:[...], paging:{page,limit,total}} for lists OR {ok:true, <resource>:<data>} for single; errors use {ok:false, fault:{code,msg}}
Discrepancies found between declared hooks in SKILL.md definitions vs. actual hook implementations in source — memory recall patching needed
set -euo pipefail kills script when grep returns no matches — use || true after grep commands
test failure remember

v6-test-fixes: FAIL when `no_multi_vendor_orders` with a clear note. Creating test seed data adds complexity (needs 3+ vendors, multi-vendor cart, checkout) and couples the test to seed correctness. A FAIL with a note is simpler and forces the agent to implement proper seed data. Use `grep -E "<P...
proactive_context(auto_ingest=True) creates "Conversation" noise in saved memories — pass auto_ingest=False to prevent

Cross-platform compatibility must be explicitly considered during both design and implementation of changes. Qt/PySide6 behavior can differ across platforms (e.g., signal-slot argument handling, window management). Always test assumptions about platform-specific behavior (macOS AppleScript, Linux xdotool, Windows). Example: @log_exceptions decorator broke PySide6 signal argument dropping — worked on macOS but failed on Linux.

MemoryBrowseDialog pagination uses client-side caching: wt-memory list is called once, full JSON parsed into _cached_memories, then cards rendered in batches of 50 from cache. The bottleneck is QFrame widget creation, not data loading — even 2000 memories parse quickly as JSON.
Use marker files (.memory) for O(1) runtime checks instead of re-parsing SKILL.md on every hook invocation. One-time check at skill start, fast lookup on every Stop event.
archive skill does not auto-trigger wt-memory save via hook; memory save is step 7 in skill instructions but agent must execute it explicitly (not automatic like Stop hook)
TRAP-B ($queryRaw pain) documented in v4-results but was accidentally omitted from v5-results.md scoring
User prefers Hungarian for technical discussions — respond in Hungarian for best engagement

async-transcript-extraction: implementation complete — Stop hook transcript extraction now runs in background via fork+disown with lockfile concurrency control. Hook exit time reduced from 5-15s to ~50ms.
team.sync_interval_ms at 15sec default generates 240 git ops/hour, causes rate limiting — must default to 120000ms (2min)
Error handling uses centralized middleware (errors.js) with `fault` format, not per-route patterns — scoring should check middleware not individual routes
Shifted benchmark to ports 4000/4001 to avoid Open WebUI conflict (3000) — all 21 config files updated

The memory hook architecture has 3 layers: CLAUDE.md ambient (covers all contexts), SKILL.md per-skill (covers skill execution), and Stop hook reminder (catches forgotten saves). A behavioral fix like Discover-Save-Tell needs to land in all 3 layers to be effective: CLAUDE.md for the rule, SKILL.md for the reminder, Stop hook already exists as safety net. When adding cross-cutting behavioral patterns, always check all 3 layers.
proactive_context() auto-saves context string as Conversation-type memory with auto_ingest=True — causes noise in memory storage; fix requires passing auto_ingest=False

Benchmark v6 insight: memory reduced C12 tokens by 50% (502K vs 1023K) but produced lower-quality implementation. Memory helps efficiency (less searching) but may reduce thoroughness — the baseline agent's exhaustive search found more issues. Consider adding recall-then-verify pattern to memory CLAUDE.md.

wt-memory sync design: orphan branch 'wt-memory' with user/machine namespacing, full export per push (dedup on import handles duplicates), .sync-state file for skip detection (sha256 on push side, commit hash on pull side), temp dir for push, git show for pull extraction. No LFS needed — memory exports are small text JSON.

shodh-memory Memory.remember() is a Rust/PyO3 native method that auto-generates UUIDs — there is no way to insert a record with a specific ID. For import dedup, use the metadata dict to store original_id and build a known-ID set from both record IDs and metadata.original_id values.
CraftBazaar (old benchmark) running next-server on ports 4000/4001 causes LogBook server to fail silently — use ports 5000/5001 instead
Fixed benchmark port assignment: 3000→4000 (Run A baseline), 3001→4001 (Run B memory) — updated all configs in benchmark/, test scripts, and run-guide.md for consistency
Port 3000 occupied by Open WebUI docker container — preflight grep bug (double output on no-match) masked the issue — fixed by switching baseline/memory to ports 4000/4001

Benchmark v2 bug: agent stopped after C09 because openspec list shows 'no-tasks' status for changes that only have proposal.md (no artifacts yet). Agent interpreted 'no-tasks' as 'nothing to do' instead of 'not started'. Fix: use results/change-NN.json files as the done-marker instead of openspec list status. Also need explicit wt-loop prompt that says 'do NOT stop until all 12 results files exist'.

Benchmark nested session limitation: wt-loop cannot be started from within a Claude Code session because the CLAUDECODE env var triggers nested session protection. The loops must be started from a regular terminal.
Fix benchmark glob code map (auto): bin/wt-loop

wt-memory sync design constraint: minimal overhead — no auto-sync, no background processes, git operations (commit/push/fetch) only when user explicitly requests via command. Avoid unnecessary traffic if nothing changed.

Archive skills (archive, bulk-archive) only need self-reflection memory hooks. Recall and mid-flow hooks belong to interactive/creative skills (explore, ff, apply, new, continue). This is a deliberate pattern split, not an omission.
v5-results.md "memory_type broken" finding was incorrect — types work properly (50 Learning, 21 Conversation, 11 Context, 1 Decision); audit script looked in wrong field causing false negative

wire-memory-hooks-deploy: archived — wt-deploy-hooks now deploys 4 hooks by default (skill, stop, memory-recall, memory-save). --no-memory flag for baselines. 3 specs synced (auto-memory-hooks-deploy, hook-auto-install, smart-memory-recall). spec-driven schema, completed successfully.
0*.md glob pattern in wt-loop detect_next_change_action() only matches 01-09, misses 10-12 — use [0-9]*.md instead

GUI dialog hide/show rule: The Control Center uses NSStatusWindowLevel (25). All dialogs opened from it MUST use self.hide() before dialog.exec() and self.show() after, otherwise the CC covers the dialog. WindowStaysOnTopHint alone is NOT enough on macOS — it only sets NSFloatingWindowLevel (~3-8). This has been a recurring bug.

v6-test-fixes: implementation complete — fixed test-12 (payout FAIL, TRAP-M render check, TRAP-N global mount, vendor regression), added C12/C02 explicit specs, TRAP-G checkout link test, hook code-map unconditional, recall-then-verify in CLAUDE.md, memory DB isolation via directory naming
Glob pattern 0*.md only matches 01-09; use [0-9]*.md to match 10-99. Broke benchmark change detection at C10+
v5-benchmark-analysis is one-off analysis change — delta specs not synced to main since they're not part of active feature development

v4 improvements over v3: (1) reflection noise filter + dedup reduced noise 27%→~15-20%, (2) agent inline saves jumped 8%→43%, (3) new transcript-based haiku extraction adds ~14% source:hook memories automatically, (4) REREAD_FILES injection forces code re-reading for C07-C12, (5) no infra bugs (v3 had C01 stuck loop, auto-stop failure).

T9 grep pattern was broken in score.sh: searched for `req.body.eventIds` but code used destructuring `const { eventIds } = req.body` — fixed pattern to match both dot-notation and destructuring styles
Use ports 4000/4001 for benchmark runs instead of 3000/3001 to avoid conflicts with persistent services (Open WebUI)
test-12 passes 71% of checks with no running server—payout check auto-passes on no_multi_vendor_orders, TRAP-M checks grep imports not renders
Port check in preflight.sh had logic bug: grep -c returns 0 with exit 1 on no match, causing "0\n0" duplication and integer parse failure — fixed with proper conditional
New trap types require sections in scoring rubric + change definitions, establishing pattern for future trap additions

SYN-02 v8 benchmark produced zero delta (83% both modes) because: (1) convention probes in test scripts leaked expected solutions via FAIL messages (e.g. "use dot.notation"), (2) C02 code changes became "memory" baked into codebase that C03-C05 sessions read—defeating memory-only test isolation

memory-save-reminder-hook: Added .memory marker file to wt-skill-start and reminder output to wt-hook-stop. When a skill has wt-memory hooks, the Stop hook reminds the agent to run recall/remember steps. Schema: spec-driven. All 14 tasks complete. Specs synced: skill-hook-automation (modified), stop-hook-memory-reminder (added).
Convention traps work best when non-standard (e.g., pagination with "entries+paging" instead of standard "page+limit")—tests real memory, not pattern matching
wt-loop-startup-info: Added --label flag, expanded startup banner (path/branch/memory/timestamp), label in terminal title, macOS AppleScript title fix. Schema: spec-driven.

memory-browse-upgrade: implementation complete — added summary/list toggle, paginated card rendering (50/page from cache), search override with mode-aware clear, context summary default view, and updated all documentation
